answers.author: Melisa Caughman
answers.text:
The City of Columbia did this in 09 when the economy was in such a bad shape and had followed what our state agencies were doing with early retirement buyouts.  The employee had to be within 1 year of retirement and were offered an early buyout option.  On the positive, this allowed us to not make significant cuts to the budgets or personnel beyond eliminating vacant positions.   Plus it created opportunities to realign staff with new duties and opportunities for advancement for some employees.  We had to take extra care an not be selective as to who was offered the buyouts and that it was open to all eligible employees.  On the negative side, this also meant that seasoned employees left.  Some of our public safety areas are still feeling the impact of the loss of trained staff.   Coupled with this, the State (of SC) was making changes to retirement which further encouraged people to retire.   So, it's a useful tool, but there can be unintend consequences - and cost - if employees with a lot of knowledge take the offer.

author: Pamela Muse
text:
An Alliance member is facing quite a few people who are close to, or already eligible for, retirement and the management team is thinking about the possibility of offering early retirement incentives to be able to put new people into place.  They have some key positions in mind and would like to know if other municipalities have done this and if it has been targeted or more widespread.
Thank you for your time and replies!
Pamela Muse
West Regional Director
Alliance for Innovation
pmuse@transformgov.org
www.transformgov.org 
www.tlgconference.org
title: Early retirement incentives
